title: Eugen Täubler
text:
Eugen Täubler (October 10, 1879 – August 13, 1953) was a German <a href="historian">historian</a> born in <a href="Gosty%C5%84">Gostyń</a>.
He studied <a href="history">history</a> in <a href="University%20of%20Berlin">Berlin</a> under <a href="Otto%20Hirschfeld">Otto Hirschfeld</a> (1843–1922), receiving his doctorate in 1904 with a dissertation titled "Die Parthernachrichten bei Josephus". From 1910 to 1914 he worked as a lecturer at the <a href="Hochschule%20f%C3%BCr%20die%20Wissenschaft%20des%20Judentums">Hochschule für die Wissenschaft des Judentums</a> (Higher Institute for Jewish Studies) in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>.
In 1927, he married the historian <a href="Selma%20Stern">Selma Stern</a>, who was a research fellow at the Akademie für die Wissenschaft des Judentums at the time.
From 1922 to 1925 he taught classes at the <a href="University%20of%20Zurich">University of Zurich</a>, and in the years 1925 to 1933 was a professor of <a href="ancient%20history">ancient history</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Heidelberg">University of Heidelberg</a>. In 1933 he was removed from his position at Heidelberg by the Nazis, and returned to teach at the Hochschule für die Wissenschaft des Judentums. After the institute's forced closure in 1941, Täubler and his wife emigrated to the United States with the help of <a href="Julian%20Morgenstern">Julian Morgenstern</a>, president of Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati. There, he became a professor at <a href="Hebrew%20Union%20College">Hebrew Union College</a> in <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a> until his death in 1953. Täubler's wife, Selma Stern-Täubler, served as the first archivist at the <a href="American%20Jewish%20Archives">American Jewish Archives</a> which were established there in 1947.
